column3:
Travis failure:
```
33.63s$ test/lint/lint-all.sh
test/lint/lint-all.sh: line 21: test/lint/lint-spelling.sh: Permission denied
^---- failure generated from test/lint/lint-spelling.sh
```

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->Note to reviewers: This pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #13998 (Scripts and tools: gitian-build.py improvements and corrections by hebasto)
* #11911 (Free CDBEnv instances when not in use by ryanofsky)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one tha
Does this mean we need to manually add words that are not recognized to the spell checker?\nIf we do this, I think this certainly needs maintenance instructions.\n
Concept ACK

@laanwj No not at all :-)  `codespell` is based on a very comprehensive list of commonly misspelled words (see the [`codespell` GitHub project](https://github.com/codespell-project/codespell) for details). Words that are not recognised as known errors are simply ignored by `codespell`.\n\nFalse positives – words recognised as errors by `codespell` but where we disagree with the classification fo

I'm... not convinced about this.

I think running this once in a while is good, just to see if there's any really awkward misspellings, but running this in travis and failing the tests just because of a misspelled word in a comment seems overkill.

As I've said before, many times, linters should be added cautiously, there to prevent real problems resulting in bugs.

Maybe it would make sense to have this run as a separate check (as in github check – https://developer.github.com/v3/checks/runs/ ). Especially with things like an AppVeyor build for MSVC (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13964#issuecomment-412852328, which already is a different check) it might be handy to have this split out of the other builds.\n\nIt would need to be hosted somewhere t

@laanwj Can you clarify your position? :-)\n\nInstead of exiting with a failure if new typos are introduced in a submitted PR we could perhaps just let `codespell` print the identified typos to the console as part of the linting process (`exit 0` instead of `exit 1`). Sounds like a good compromise?

Now only warns in case of spelling errors by writing identified spellings to standard output (with `exit 0` instead of `exit 1`). That way spelling errors will be noticed quickly without blocking Travis. Should be a good compromise hopefully :-)

Also rebased!

Example output:

```
$ test/lint/lint-spelling.sh; echo $?
src/streams.h:532: signficant  ==> significant

False posit

This can be seen in action on https://travis-ci.org/bitcoin/bitcoin/jobs/421142979 – it correctly identifies the misspelled word "signficant" which was introduced in fe943f99bf0a2bbb12e30bc4803c0337e3c95b93. That commit was part of #12254 ("BIP 158: Compact Block Filters for Light Clients") which merged a day ago. FWIW, it was a extremely thoroughly reviewed PR with many reviewers but only `codesp

Rebased and fixed the typos that `codespell` found in the newly introduced documentation.\n\n`codespell` catched the "account" typo first reported by @promag in PR #14023 post-merge: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14023#discussion_r213136227

@jnewbery Thanks for the encouraging review! PR updated – please re-review :-)\n\nIf this PR is merged I'll look if there is some smart way to use Travis console output folding or similar to make the spelling warnings more prominent in the Travis interface.

>  I'd lean toward having the linter fail on spelling errors rather than just warn (which will no doubt be ignored).

I still strongly disagree with this, I don't think we should pile up linters for cosmetic issues.

The original idea of them was to flag serious issues that can result in bugs.

Failing the tests on some supposed spelling error in a comment really, goes too far.
@laanwj What about enabling it on a warning level (as the PR is currently formulated) instead of error level? Could that be a good compromise? :-)

> I still strongly disagree with this

ok, I won't rehash the debate that we've all had in countless other PRs already :)

My point was merely that warnings tend to get ignored, so in general I think they're less useful than errors. I don't have any strong opinion on this PR though.

Yes, warning is ok with me

Though I think it would be best if one of us runs this periodically, for example for every major release, and fixes the jarring typos. I don't think this is something that necessarily needs to run continuously.
@jnewbery When thinking about it again I agree regarding "deselect" vs "unselect". Now added it to the ignore list instead and removed that commit. Please re-review :-)

Concept ACK for warnings. Maybe Drahbot can point out typos. In addition we could fix the ones we missed as part of the release process.\n\nutACK 4a98785 (though maybe squash the first and last commit)
@Sjors Squashed. Please re-review :-)
utACK b5ee29e460dc36066bac68e041073100c0eca20e
@Sjors @fanquake Updated to address @fanquake's comment. Please re-review :-)
utACK f8a81f73ac4fee82488806c2b384b36e8ee2acdf
utACK ada3562 could squash

so in case anyone cares, i'm not happy about this

"can we add this?"
"well, "

> I still strongly disagree with this, I don't think we should pile up linters for cosmetic issues.
> The original idea of them was to flag serious issues that can result in bugs.
> Failing the tests on some supposed spelling error in a comment really, goes too far.

"but… can we add it if it only war

@laanwj Oh, I wasn't aware of the policy change introduced in #14179 so I don't have anything meaningful to add about that. Setting the discussion about that merge decision aside:\n\nDo you have a link to the Travis failure? It would be interesting to see if it was a true positive or a false positive that caused `codespell` to complain.
It came up when someone tried to name a mutex `mut`. Seems unreasonable to demand variables have English word names...

yes it came up on IRC @karel-3d
```
08:29 < karelb> I am trying to run my fork of bitcoind on travis.... and travis stops with this
08:29 < karelb> src/threadinterrupt.cpp:25: mut  ==> must, mutt, moot
08:29 < karelb> Warning: codespell identified likely spelling errors
08:29 < karelb> failure generated from test/lint/lint-spelling.sh
08:29 < karelb> .....ummmmm, ok?
08:30 < karelb>

Oh, that sounds really strange.

I'm unable to reproduce locally:

```
$ grep mut src/threadinterrupt.cpp
        LOCK(mut);
    WAIT_LOCK(mut, lock);
$ codespell src/threadinterrupt.cpp
$ echo $?
0
```

Anyone who has been able to reproduce?
I was able to reproduce after upgrading `codespell`. Will submit a PR fixing this.
@practicalswift Which versions of codespell?

@scravy 

```
$ pip3 install codespell --upgrade
Requirement already up-to-date: codespell in /usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages
$ codespell --version
1.14.0
```
Fixed in #14495 :-)

@scravy Seems like this was introduced somewhere between `1.13.1` and `1.14.0`. We're pinning to `1.13.0` in Travis. I don't know how a more recent got installed in @karel-3d:s Travis setup. @karel-3d, do you know? :-)

I cloned the repo, did some experimental changes, and used Travis-ci.org.

The build is here

https://travis-ci.org/karel-3d/bitcoin/builds/442019337

It's branched from this commit, 18 days old. (Maybe it will go away if I rebase on current master?)

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/0809e68a9084630ff4d11ec0503a3d0ab52bc6d7

Oh yeah. It seems I have branched the master *before* this commit

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/d10f2cd7d8506aec8b406c346b35d3c31f0f37df

Which means that if I rebase to master, it would indeed go away.
@karel-3d Thanks for the clarification! That explains the mystery :-)

Can use
```
addons:
  apt:
    packages:
    - codespell
```
to avoid sudo
Oh that is much cleaner! Thanks!
nit: using the long form options here would be more self-documenting: `--disable-colors --quiet-level=`
Why are these changes necessary? There are plenty more leading `\n` in this file.
nit: `codespell` recommends installation via `pip`:\nhttps://github.com/codespell-project/codespell
Good point! Now fixed.
The old Ubuntu packaged version didn't understand `\n` and thus flagged "nTo" as a typo. That seems to have been fixed in the more recent `pip` installed version.
Good point! Now fixed
why?
Should probably be a scripted diff
Yeah I would add these to `test/lint/lint-spelling.ignore-words.txt` rather than use `:` to separate them.
Good point! Now fixed using a `scripted-diff` :-)
I've never seen a colon used in this way. Why not mmap'ed?
Is unselect really not ok? https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/unselect.

@jnewbery I found this: https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/18465/unselect-or-deselect\n\nI'm happy to revert this specific change and add an exclude instead if this change is controversial :-)
Both seem fine to me, but I don't care strongly.
If unselect is in the ignore list, why is this being changed?
Good point. Fixed!

contrib/linearize/linearize-data.py:                os.utime(self.outFname, (int(time.time()), self.highTS))
contrib/linearize/linearize-data.py:                    os.utime(self.outFname, (int(time.time()), self.highTS))
